data.title: Scanning the horizon: challenges facing UK local government in 2024
data.meta_description: Futureproofing local government in the face of myriad challenges requires innovation and elevated strategic planning, writes Adele Gritten, chief
data.text:
Futureproofing local government in the face of myriad challenges requires innovation and elevated strategic planning, writes Adele Gritten, chief executive of Local Partnerships. Sponsored comment from Local Partnerships.

As we step into 2024, local government finds itself at a critical juncture, facing a myriad of challenges that demand innovative solutions and elevated strategic planning skillsets.

From global pandemic aftermath to the evolving technological landscape and the pressing issues of sustainability, local authorities must navigate a complex set of challenges to ensure the wellbeing and progress of local communities. Below are some of those challenges and the ways in which organisations like Local Partnerships can help.

Continued post-pandemic recovery

As local authorities continue to rebuild communities, they must address the ongoing economic, social and health consequences of the pandemic. They must collaborate with businesses, healthcare providers and community organisations in ways they may not have done previously, to formulate comprehensive long-term recovery plans that promote resilience and community wellbeing.

Digital transformation

The accelerated pace of technological advancement poses both opportunities and challenges for local government. The adoption of digital tools and platforms is crucial for improving service delivery, enhancing communication and streamlining administrative processes.

Local government needs to ensure inclusivity in its digital strategies, ensuring all residents can benefit

However, a digital divide remains, with some communities still lacking access or ability to navigate essential technology (and we often forget this). Local government needs to ensure inclusivity in its digital strategies, addressing disparities and ensuring all residents can benefit from the opportunities technology offers.

Housing crisis

The shortage of affordable housing continues to be an issue. Local authorities face the challenge of providing adequate housing while balancing environmental sustainability and statutory planning requirements alongside wider climate emergency declaration pledges. Ongoing collaboration with private developers to provide innovative housing solutions will inevitably need to be further explored.

Climate change and sustainability

As the impacts of climate change become increasingly evident, local government plays a pivotal role in mitigating and adapting to these changes. The UK’s targets for achieving net zero carbon emissions and local authority pledges must align into cohesive policies with common goals. This includes ongoing local economy investment in renewable energy, promoting sustainable transportation and implementing measures to enhance resilience against extreme weather events.

Balancing economic development with environmental sustainability is a delicate task that requires strategic planning and community engagement in ways perhaps not previously considered. Community power via community buy-in has never been so important.

Social inequality

Persistent social inequalities present challenges for local government striving to ­create inclusive and equitable communities. Addressing issues such as income ­disparity, educational inequality and access to healthcare is essential for fostering social cohesion. There is a continued theme of partnership working – local authorities must work collaboratively with community organisations and businesses to implement targeted initiatives that uplift marginalised groups and promote equal opportunities for all residents.

Demographic shifts

UK demography continues to evolve with an ageing population, increased cultural diversity and ongoing temporary accommodation challenges due to migration.

Local government must continue to adapt services to meet the needs of changing communities. This includes providing accessible healthcare services for the elderly, and promoting cultural integration and social cohesion, thereby developing policies that accommodate ongoing societal change.

Proactive planning for demographic shifts is crucial for ensuring the wellbeing and cohesion of communities and must be built into local plans as well as individual local authority business plans. Harnessing quality data to support this is essential.

Financial constraints

Doing less with more is the name of the game. Strained budgets are making it challenging to fund essential services and infrastructure projects; an ongoing stream of section 114 notices and best value notices will not come as a surprise this year.

Sound strategic financial management, collaboration with other levels of government and exploring alternative funding sources are vital for local authorities to overcome financial constraints and deliver quality services.

Cybersecurity

With increased reliance on digital platforms, local government becomes more vulnerable to cyber threats. Safeguarding sensitive data and ensuring the integrity of critical systems are paramount. Local authorities must invest in robust cybersecurity measures, employee training and contingency plans to protect themselves. Building resilience in the face of evolving threats is essential to maintaining public trust and the smooth functioning of local government operations.

Public engagement and trust

Building and maintaining public trust is arguably the cornerstone of effective governance. Local government must prioritise transparency, open communication and meaningful public engagement to foster positivity within communities. Establishing mechanisms for citizen participation in decision-making processes, responding to feedback and being accountable for actions are vital components of a trustworthy and effective local government.

In summary, Local Partnerships provides support to help futureproof public services and support local government resilience.

Owned by the public sector, working for the public sector, we provide value and efficacy for the public purse and would be delighted to talk to you further about your 2024 challenges and how, specifically, we could help your local authority to succeed.

Adele Gritten is chief executive of Local Partnerships

How can we help?

Organisations like Local Partnerships play a key role in assisting local government in 2024 and beyond, by providing strategic advice, operational support and alternative thinking to problems that address the complex challenges. Below are ways we can help.

Strategic business planning

Assist in developing and refining local government’s strategic vision, mission and goals (business planning) and operational route maps and blueprints for success.

Business case support and critical friend reviews.

Performance improvement

Identify opportunities for (further) operational efficiencies and cost reduction.

Support the implementation of performance measurement systems to track and evaluate key performance indicators.

Help streamline processes and eliminate redundancies to improve service delivery.

Digital transformation

Provide expertise in adopting and implementing digital technologies to enhance government services (transformation support).

Help develop digital strategies for e-governance, online service delivery and wider citizen engagement.

Assist in cybersecurity/governance measures to protect sensitive data.

Data analytics

Utilise data analytics to derive insights for evidence-based decision-making.

Implement data-driven policies and strategies to address specific challenges.

Enhance data governance and management practices internally and with third parties.

Financial management

Financial consulting to improve budgeting, financial planning, and resource allocation.

Conduct financial assessments to identify areas for cost savings and revenue generation.

Provide expertise in securing funding through grants and partnerships.

Support with procurement, PFI, PPP and wider commercial efficacy initiatives.

Change management

Assist in managing organisational change and overcoming resistance to new initiatives (critical friend, trusted advisor and in-house capacity and capability support).

Help develop communication strategies to engage and inform both internal and external stakeholders.

Provide training to equip employees with the skills needed for evolving roles.

Policy development

Support local government in creating and updating policies that align with current and emerging needs.

Conduct policy impact assessments and assurance/gateway reviews including helping with regulatory change implementation.

Community engagement

Facilitate or advise on community involvement in decision-making.

Develop strategies for effective communication with the public.

Support with the implementation of programmes to enhance civic participation and local transparency.

Sustainability and resilience

Advise on sustainable practices and initiatives including net zero, carbon reduction, heat networks, green finance and more.

Assist in developing resilience plans to address environmental, economic and social challenges.

Advise on and support the implementation of green infrastructure projects and sustainable development strategies.

Collaboration and partnerships

Facilitate collaboration between local government entities and external stakeholders.

Identify opportunities for public/private partnerships and community collaborations.

Strengthen regional cooperation for shared services and resource optimisation.
